note.p: John Jones Pettus was Mississippi's governor during the first three years of the Civil War.

Born in Wilson County, Tennessee, on October 9, 1813, Pettus moved to Limestone County, Alabama, as a child. In 1835, he moved to Mississippi and eventually began a law practice in Scooba, Mississippi. He married Permelia Winston in the 1840s. She passed away in 1857, and in 1861 Pettus married Susan Hewell.

Pettus began pursuing a political career in the mid-1840s, first serving as a state representative for Kemper County. He won a state Senate election in 1848 and by 1853 had risen to president of the Mississippi Senate. Then, in January 1854, Governor Henry S. Foote resigned in protest before Governor-elect John J. McRae was inaugurated. Pettus’ position in the Senate placed him next in line to fill the governor’s vacancy, and he was sworn in as Mississippi’s interim executive on January 7, 1854. He served in that role for only three days, before McRae was inaugurated on January 10.

Pettus won the governor’s election in 1859. By that time, he had become a notable secessionist. He advocated for the creation of an independent Confederacy dedicated to preserving slavery. When Abraham Lincoln was elected president in 1860, Pettus called forth a special legislative session in Mississippi and pressed state representatives to hold a secession convention. His efforts succeeded, as such convention assembled in January 1861 and voted in support of secession, declaring the State of Mississippi out of the Union. Pettus won reelection for governor in 1861 and served until his term ended in 1863. Mississippi’s Constitution had a two-term limit for the governor’s office, leaving Pettus unable to run again. He took a commission as a colonel in the Mississippi State Troops and served until the end of the war. Shortly thereafter, Pettus moved to Arkansas. He applied for a presidential pardon according to President Andrew Johnson’s Reconstruction policies, but was denied three times.
Pettus died of pneumonia on January 25, 1867. He is buried in Flat Bayou Cemetery, Jefferson County, Arkansas.

note.p: Andrew Boyd Dilworth was a politician in Mississippi before and during the Civil War. Born on December 14, 1814, in Rockingham County, North Carolina, Dilworth moved to Mississippi as a young man and became a farmer. He got involved in local politics and government work, winning an election to the Mississippi House of Representatives in 1846 as a Democrat. He served in the legislature until 1850, and then was appointed Secretary of State of Mississippi in 1855. He remained secretary until 1860, then served as state auditor (overseeing government finances) during the first year of the Civil War. In 1862, Dilworth was appointed a Quartermaster General in the Confederate army and was stationed in Iuka, Mississippi. Among his more notable duties involved arranging release of Confederate prisoners of war held at Camp Douglas in Chicago, Illinois. Dilworth died on July 2, 1894. He was married to Sarah Catherine Taylor and had three children. He is buried in Biggersville, Mississippi.

Located near Iuka in Tishomingo County, Mississippi, Camp Iuka was a Confederate training camp established in the summer of 1861. (Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 429, 527, 629)

Located in Tishomingo County, Iuka was founded some time before 1850 and serves as the county seat. (Mississippi Encyclopedia; Wikipedia; Rowland, Mississippi, 948; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)

div.p: I hope you will pardon me for writing to prefer a request to you after my letter of the day before yesterday which doubtless you will have received ere this will reach you—You will know [?] [Genl?] in behalf of [?] [?] must plead my excuse, for it is in that I [?] to pardon any trouble which I may give.
I am in Camp here with 94 men exclusion of the Officers of my Company. Being engaged for the men in the Service of the Confedrate States—For the

weeks past Have been engaged gathering up the muskets and ^Missi^ Rifles in the repair in which taken, and recorded in [?] [?] some 50 odd guns altogether. Since we came here we have picked up a few muskets (about 12) three or four of which are in tolerably good order. the others being without locks others with broken tubes or hammers or [?] defection. Some few of the Missi Rifles are private prop=erty but we have in all some 55 guns (muskets & rifles) which we can dispose of. The muskets wich we brought from home have been changed from flint to percussion, but it's work men [?] [?] the tubes being so made that theybreak with the force of the blow of the hammer & the hammers are of brass which some wear out.

The object of my letter is to beg of you, to exchange for its use guns, Sir. In service for those which I have. We would like [?] uniform guns for we have 94 in number—the guns I have could easily be repaired in shops. there is no workshop here else I should be tempted to beg to have it done at tribute expense. and we are about to enter into active Service & the Confederacy is in need of the men & guns immediately. May God hope that if it be in your power you will comply with this request, by funding you will oblide greatly
Yrbey Svt
in reference to guns & wants to exchange same
Impossible to ex-change guns I am sending off as fast as I get a small lot to gather—Col Dilworth will furnish camp Equipage & [?] in stores & charge Confederate States
